intro: Iberis intermedia subsp. durandii, commonly known as the Durand's candytuft, is a perennial flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of southern Europe. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes mustard and cabbage plants, and is characterized by its compact growth habit and profuse white or pale yellow flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, with hairy, linear leaves that are arranged alternately along the stems. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in alpine and rocky habitats. The flowers bloom in early spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
